title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: functions designed summarize categorical data, including: Binary variables (e.g., Unselected/Selected) Nominal variables (e.g., woman/man/non-binary) Functions summarize categorical data start prefix cat_: cat_tbl cat_group_tbl

title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: functions handle multiple response data, can include: Binary variables (e.g., Unselected/Selected) Ordinal variables (e.g., never, sometimes, often) Likert Likert-type variables (e.g., strongly disagree strongly agree) Functions multiple response data start prefix select_: select_tbl select_group_tbl

title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: functions used continuous data, : Interval-level variables (e.g., test scores) Ratio-level variables (e.g., age) Functions continuous data start prefix mean_: mean_tbl mean_group_tbl learn functions work, read next sections.

title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: cat_tbl() function can used generate frequency table categorical variable. can exclude certain values eliminate missing values data using ignore na.rm arguments, respectively. Finally, can choose information return using argument.
code: cat_tbl(data = nlsy, var = "race") ## # A tibble: 3 × 3 ##   race                   count percent ##   <chr>                  <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                    868   0.292 ## 2 Hispanic                 631   0.212 ## 3 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic  1477   0.496 cat_tbl(data = nlsy,          var = "race",         ignore = "Black",         na.rm = TRUE) ## # A tibble: 2 × 3 ##   race                   count percent ##   <chr>                  <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Hispanic                 631   0.299 ## 2 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic  1477   0.701 # Default: counts and percentages cat_tbl(data = nlsy,          var = "race",         ignore = "Black",         na.rm = TRUE) ## # A tibble: 2 × 3 ##   race                   count percent ##   <chr>                  <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Hispanic                 631   0.299 ## 2 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic  1477   0.701 # Counts only cat_tbl(data = nlsy,          var = "race",         ignore = "Black",         na.rm = TRUE,         only = "count") ## # A tibble: 2 × 2 ##   race                   count ##   <chr>                  <int> ## 1 Hispanic                 631 ## 2 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic  1477 # Percents only cat_tbl(data = nlsy,          var = "race",         ignore = "Black",         na.rm = TRUE,         only = "percent") ## # A tibble: 2 × 2 ##   race                   percent ##   <chr>                    <dbl> ## 1 Hispanic                 0.299 ## 2 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic   0.701

title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: create grouped frequency table two categorical variables (.e., contingency table), use cat_group_tbl() function. Like cat_tbl(), option exclude certain values omit missing values (row /column). want ignore one value per row column, provide named list: Use margins argument define percentages calculated shown resulting table: Finally, can choose information return using argument.
code: cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "gender",               col_var = "bthwht") ## # A tibble: 4 × 4 ##   gender bthwht count percent ##    <dbl>  <dbl> <int>   <dbl> ## 1      0      0  1340  0.450  ## 2      0      1   123  0.0413 ## 3      1      0  1409  0.473  ## 4      1      1   104  0.0349 cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               ignore = c(race = "Non-Black,Non-Hispanic"),               pivot = "wider") ## # A tibble: 2 × 5 ##   race     count_bthwht_0 count_bthwht_1 percent_bthwht_0 percent_bthwht_1 ##   <chr>             <int>          <int>            <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1 Black               766            102            0.511           0.0680 ## 2 Hispanic            589             42            0.393           0.0280 cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               ignore = list(race = c("Non-Black,Non-Hispanic", "Hispanic")),               pivot = "wider") ## # A tibble: 1 × 5 ##   race  count_bthwht_0 count_bthwht_1 percent_bthwht_0 percent_bthwht_1 ##   <chr>          <int>          <int>            <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1 Black            766            102            0.882            0.118 # Default: percentages across the full table sum to one cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               pivot = "wider") ## # A tibble: 3 × 5 ##   race           count_bthwht_0 count_bthwht_1 percent_bthwht_0 percent_bthwht_1 ##   <chr>                   <int>          <int>            <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1 Black                     766            102            0.257           0.0343 ## 2 Hispanic                  589             42            0.198           0.0141 ## 3 Non-Black,Non…           1394             83            0.468           0.0279 # Rowwise: percentages sum to one across columns within each row cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               margins = "rows",               pivot = "wider") ## # A tibble: 3 × 5 ##   race           count_bthwht_0 count_bthwht_1 percent_bthwht_0 percent_bthwht_1 ##   <chr>                   <int>          <int>            <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1 Black                     766            102            0.882           0.118  ## 2 Hispanic                  589             42            0.933           0.0666 ## 3 Non-Black,Non…           1394             83            0.944           0.0562 # Columnwise: percentages within each column sum to one cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               margins = "columns",               pivot = "wider") ## # A tibble: 3 × 5 ##   race           count_bthwht_0 count_bthwht_1 percent_bthwht_0 percent_bthwht_1 ##   <chr>                   <int>          <int>            <dbl>            <dbl> ## 1 Black                     766            102            0.279            0.449 ## 2 Hispanic                  589             42            0.214            0.185 ## 3 Non-Black,Non…           1394             83            0.507            0.366 # Default: counts and percentages cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE) ## # A tibble: 6 × 4 ##   race                   bthwht count percent ##   <chr>                   <dbl> <int>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                       0   766  0.257  ## 2 Black                       1   102  0.0343 ## 3 Hispanic                    0   589  0.198  ## 4 Hispanic                    1    42  0.0141 ## 5 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      0  1394  0.468  ## 6 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      1    83  0.0279 # Counts only cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               only = "count") ## # A tibble: 6 × 3 ##   race                   bthwht count ##   <chr>                   <dbl> <int> ## 1 Black                       0   766 ## 2 Black                       1   102 ## 3 Hispanic                    0   589 ## 4 Hispanic                    1    42 ## 5 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      0  1394 ## 6 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      1    83 # Percents only cat_group_tbl(data = nlsy,               row_var = "race",               col_var = "bthwht",               na.rm.row_var = TRUE,               only = "percent") ## # A tibble: 6 × 3 ##   race                   bthwht percent ##   <chr>                   <dbl>   <dbl> ## 1 Black                       0  0.257  ## 2 Black                       1  0.0343 ## 3 Hispanic                    0  0.198  ## 4 Hispanic                    1  0.0141 ## 5 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      0  0.468  ## 6 Non-Black,Non-Hispanic      1  0.0279

title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: select_tbl(), can produce summary table multiple response variables variable stem. variable stem shared prefix set related variable names, typically used represent common concept across similar survey items. example, depressive dataset contains eight variables share variable stem: dep, one representing different item (statement question) used measure depression: select_tbl() function lets summarize responses items showing many respondents chose answer option (.e., value) every variable. can also use ignore na_removal arguments exclude values data specify missing values handled. default, missing values removed listwise, can set na_removal pairwise pairwise removal instead: Set pivot argument wider reshape resulting table wide format. default, summary table presented long format. can use var_labels argument include variable labels summary table make variable names easier interpret: Finally, can choose information return using argument.
code: names(depressive) ##  [1] "cid"   "race"  "sex"   "yob"   "dep_1" "dep_2" "dep_3" "dep_4" "dep_5" ## [10] "dep_6" "dep_7" "dep_8" select_tbl(data = depressive, var_stem = "dep") ## # A tibble: 24 × 4 ##    variable values count percent ##    <chr>     <int> <int>   <dbl> ##  1 dep_1         1   109  0.0678 ##  2 dep_1         2   689  0.429  ##  3 dep_1         3   809  0.503  ##  4 dep_2         1   144  0.0896 ##  5 dep_2         2   746  0.464  ##  6 dep_2         3   717  0.446  ##  7 dep_3         1  1162  0.723  ##  8 dep_3         2   392  0.244  ##  9 dep_3         3    53  0.0330 ## 10 dep_4         1   601  0.374  ## # ℹ 14 more rows # Default listwise removal, value '3' removed from data select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",             ignore = 3) ## # A tibble: 16 × 4 ##    variable values count percent ##    <chr>     <int> <int>   <dbl> ##  1 dep_1         1    37   0.167 ##  2 dep_1         2   185   0.833 ##  3 dep_2         1    47   0.212 ##  4 dep_2         2   175   0.788 ##  5 dep_3         1   133   0.599 ##  6 dep_3         2    89   0.401 ##  7 dep_4         1   108   0.486 ##  8 dep_4         2   114   0.514 ##  9 dep_5         1    61   0.275 ## 10 dep_5         2   161   0.725 ## 11 dep_6         1    86   0.387 ## 12 dep_6         2   136   0.613 ## 13 dep_7         1   126   0.568 ## 14 dep_7         2    96   0.432 ## 15 dep_8         1    81   0.365 ## 16 dep_8         2   141   0.635 # Pairwise removal, value '3' removed from data select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",             ignore = 3,            na_removal = "pairwise") ## # A tibble: 16 × 4 ##    variable values count percent ##    <chr>     <int> <int>   <dbl> ##  1 dep_1         1   120   0.145 ##  2 dep_1         2   709   0.855 ##  3 dep_2         1   151   0.165 ##  4 dep_2         2   762   0.835 ##  5 dep_3         1  1192   0.746 ##  6 dep_3         2   406   0.254 ##  7 dep_4         1   611   0.416 ##  8 dep_4         2   856   0.584 ##  9 dep_5         1   206   0.264 ## 10 dep_5         2   574   0.736 ## 11 dep_6         1   399   0.312 ## 12 dep_6         2   879   0.688 ## 13 dep_7         1  1046   0.674 ## 14 dep_7         2   507   0.326 ## 15 dep_8         1   323   0.287 ## 16 dep_8         2   801   0.713 # Default longer format select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep") ## # A tibble: 24 × 4 ##    variable values count percent ##    <chr>     <int> <int>   <dbl> ##  1 dep_1         1   109  0.0678 ##  2 dep_1         2   689  0.429  ##  3 dep_1         3   809  0.503  ##  4 dep_2         1   144  0.0896 ##  5 dep_2         2   746  0.464  ##  6 dep_2         3   717  0.446  ##  7 dep_3         1  1162  0.723  ##  8 dep_3         2   392  0.244  ##  9 dep_3         3    53  0.0330 ## 10 dep_4         1   601  0.374  ## # ℹ 14 more rows # Wider format select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",            pivot = "wider") ## # A tibble: 8 × 7 ##   variable count_value_1 count_value_2 count_value_3 percent_value_1 ##   <chr>            <int>         <int>         <int>           <dbl> ## 1 dep_1              109           689           809          0.0678 ## 2 dep_2              144           746           717          0.0896 ## 3 dep_3             1162           392            53          0.723  ## 4 dep_4              601           836           170          0.374  ## 5 dep_5              194           556           857          0.121  ## 6 dep_6              387           860           360          0.241  ## 7 dep_7             1028           490            89          0.640  ## 8 dep_8              317           784           506          0.197  ## # ℹ 2 more variables: percent_value_2 <dbl>, percent_value_3 <dbl> select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",            pivot = "wider",            var_labels = c(              dep_1="how often child feels sad and blue",              dep_2="how often child feels nervous, tense, or on edge",              dep_3="how often child feels happy",              dep_4="how often child feels bored",              dep_5="how often child feels lonely",              dep_6="how often child feels tired or worn out",              dep_7="how often child feels excited about something",              dep_8="how often child feels too busy to get everything"            ) ) ## # A tibble: 8 × 8 ##   variable variable_label              count_value_1 count_value_2 count_value_3 ##   <chr>    <chr>                               <int>         <int>         <int> ## 1 dep_1    how often child feels sad …           109           689           809 ## 2 dep_2    how often child feels nerv…           144           746           717 ## 3 dep_3    how often child feels happy          1162           392            53 ## 4 dep_4    how often child feels bored           601           836           170 ## 5 dep_5    how often child feels lone…           194           556           857 ## 6 dep_6    how often child feels tire…           387           860           360 ## 7 dep_7    how often child feels exci…          1028           490            89 ## 8 dep_8    how often child feels too …           317           784           506 ## # ℹ 3 more variables: percent_value_1 <dbl>, percent_value_2 <dbl>, ## #   percent_value_3 <dbl> # Default: counts and percentages select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",            pivot = "wider") ## # A tibble: 8 × 7 ##   variable count_value_1 count_value_2 count_value_3 percent_value_1 ##   <chr>            <int>         <int>         <int>           <dbl> ## 1 dep_1              109           689           809          0.0678 ## 2 dep_2              144           746           717          0.0896 ## 3 dep_3             1162           392            53          0.723  ## 4 dep_4              601           836           170          0.374  ## 5 dep_5              194           556           857          0.121  ## 6 dep_6              387           860           360          0.241  ## 7 dep_7             1028           490            89          0.640  ## 8 dep_8              317           784           506          0.197  ## # ℹ 2 more variables: percent_value_2 <dbl>, percent_value_3 <dbl> # Counts only select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",            pivot = "wider",            only = "count") ## # A tibble: 8 × 4 ##   variable count_value_1 count_value_2 count_value_3 ##   <chr>            <int>         <int>         <int> ## 1 dep_1              109           689           809 ## 2 dep_2              144           746           717 ## 3 dep_3             1162           392            53 ## 4 dep_4              601           836           170 ## 5 dep_5              194           556           857 ## 6 dep_6              387           860           360 ## 7 dep_7             1028           490            89 ## 8 dep_8              317           784           506 # Percents only select_tbl(data = depressive,             var_stem = "dep",            pivot = "wider",            only = "percent") ## 2 dep_2             0.0896           0.464          0.446  ## 3 dep_3             0.723            0.244          0.0330 ## 4 dep_4             0.374            0.520          0.106  ## 5 dep_5             0.121            0.346          0.533  ## 6 dep_6             0.241            0.535          0.224  ## 7 dep_7             0.640            0.305          0.0554 ## 8 dep_8             0.197            0.488          0.315

what: Summarize multiple response variables by group or pattern
title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: select_group_tbl(), can create summary table multiple response variables variable stem, grouped either another variable dataset matching pattern variable names. example, often want summarize survey responses demographic variables like gender, age, race: cat_group_tbl(), can define values exclude handle missing data. excluding values, use var_stem argument specify values omit across variables sharing stem. Use list need exclude multiple values var_stem group variable group_type variable can use margins argument define percentages calculated shown resulting table: Another application select_group_tbl() summarizing responses based matching pattern, survey time points (e.g., waves). use feature, set group_type pattern enter pattern search group argument. example, stem_social_psych dataset includes set variables responded students two different time points (“w1” “w2”). can summarize responses variables using following approach: Use group_name argument assign descriptive name column containing matched pattern values. can use var_labels argument include variable labels summary table make variable names easier interpret: Finally, can choose information return using argument.
code: dep_recoded <-    depressive |>   dplyr::mutate(     race = dplyr::case_match(.x = race,                              1 ~ "Hispanic",                               2 ~ "Black",                               3 ~ "Non-Black/Non-Hispanic",                              .default = NA)   ) |>   dplyr::mutate(     dplyr::across(       .cols = dplyr::starts_with("dep"),       .fns = ~ dplyr::case_when(.x == 1 ~ "often",                                  .x == 2 ~ "sometimes",                                  .x == 3 ~ "hardly ever")     ))  # longer format select_group_tbl(data = dep_recoded,                   var_stem = "dep",                  group = "race",                  pivot = "longer") ## # A tibble: 72 × 5 ##    variable race                   values      count percent ##    <chr>    <chr>                  <chr>       <int>   <dbl> ##  1 dep_1    Black                  hardly ever   248  0.154  ##  2 dep_1    Black                  often          45  0.0280 ##  3 dep_1    Black                  sometimes     194  0.121  ##  4 dep_1    Hispanic               hardly ever   187  0.116  ##  5 dep_1    Hispanic               often          28  0.0174 ##  6 dep_1    Hispanic               sometimes     155  0.0965 ##  7 dep_1    Non-Black/Non-Hispanic hardly ever   374  0.233  ##  8 dep_1    Non-Black/Non-Hispanic often          36  0.0224 ##  9 dep_1    Non-Black/Non-Hispanic sometimes     340  0.212  ## 10 dep_2    Black                  hardly ever   234  0.146  ## # ℹ 62 more rows # wider format select_group_tbl(data = dep_recoded,                   var_stem = "dep",                  group = "race",                  pivot = "wider") ## # A tibble: 24 × 8 ##    variable values   count_race_Black count_race_Hispanic count_race_Non-Black…¹ ##    <chr>    <chr>               <int>               <int>                  <int> ##  1 dep_1    hardly …              248                 187                    374 ## # ℹ 14 more rows ## # ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​`count_race_Non-Black/Non-Hispanic` ## # ℹ 3 more variables: percent_race_Black <dbl>, percent_race_Hispanic <dbl>, ## #   `percent_race_Non-Black/Non-Hispanic` <dbl> # Default listwise removal: 'often' value removed from all # dep_ variables, and 'Non-Black/Non-Hispanic' value removed # from race variable select_group_tbl(data = dep_recoded,                   var_stem = "dep",                  group = "race",                  pivot = "longer",                  ignore = c(dep = "often", race = "Non-Black/Non-Hispanic")) ## title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: mean_tbl() function, can summarize series continuous variables share variable stem. resulting table provides descriptive statistics variable, including mean, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, number non-missing values. Like functions package, can use ignore argument specify values exclude variables associated provided variable stem. can also specify missing values removed: Including variable labels summary table can help make variable names easier interpret. Finally, can choose information return using argument.

2 HHC_PCT_HHA_PHYS_THERAPY  56.7  48.8     0   100  3227 ## 3 HHC_PCT_HHA_OCC_THERAPY   52.4  48.3     0   100  3227 ## 4 HHC_PCT_HHA_SPEECH        49.1  47.6     0   100  3227 ## 5 HHC_PCT_HHA_MEDICAL       42.2  46.2     0   100  3227 ## 6 HHC_PCT_HHA_AIDE          55.1  48.6     0   100  3227 mean_tbl(data = sdoh,           var_stem = "HHC_PCT",          ignore = 0) ## # A tibble: 6 × 6 ##   variable                  mean    sd    min   max  nobs ## what: Summarize continuous variables by group or pattern
title: Introduction to summarytabl
text: mean_group_tbl() function, can produce summary table series continuous variables sharing variable stem, grouped either another variable dataset matching pattern variable names. example, often want present summary statistics responses demographic variables like region, gender, age, race: select_group_tbl(), can specify values exclude whether omit missing values. sure use var_stem argument provide determine values exclude variables sharing stem. Use list want exclude several values var_stem group variable: Another application mean_group_tbl() summarizing responses based matching pattern, survey time points (e.g., waves). use feature, set group_type pattern enter pattern search group argument. Use group_name argument give descriptive label column matched patterns grouping variable values, var_labels argument add labels variables summary table. Finally, can choose information return using argument.

what: Generate Summary Tables for Continuous, Ordinal, and Categorical Data
title: Generate Summary Tables for Continuous, Ordinal, and Categorical Data
text: summarytabl R package provides functions tabulating summarizing continuous, ordinal, categorical variables data frames. summarytabl designed streamline descriptive analysis categorical, ordinal, continuous data. Whether ’re working report presentation, summarytabl simplifies process summarizing data insightful interpretation effective communication.

title: Generate Summary Tables for Continuous, Ordinal, and Categorical Data
text: Install summarytabl package CRAN using following command: latest updates, install development version package GitHub:
code: install.packages("summarytabl") remotes::install_github("anyamemensah/summarytabl", build_vignettes = TRUE)

what: Summarize a categorical variable by a grouping variable — cat_group_tbl
title: Summarize a categorical variable by a grouping variable — cat_group_tbl
text: cat_group_tbl() summarizes nominal categorical variables grouping variable, returning frequency counts percentages. supports long wide output formats, handles missing data, allows percentage calculations across rows, columns, full table.

title: Summarize a categorical variable by a grouping variable — cat_group_tbl
code: cat_group_tbl(   data,   row_var,   col_var,   margins = "all",   na.rm.row_var = FALSE,   na.rm.col_var = FALSE,   pivot = "longer",   only = NULL,   ignore = NULL )

title: Summarize a categorical variable by a grouping variable — cat_group_tbl
text: data data frame. row_var character string name variable data containing categorical data. primary categorical variable. col_var character string name variable data containing categorical data. margins character string determines percentage values calculated; whether sum one across rows, columns, entire table (.e., ). Defaults , can also set rows columns. na.rm.row_var logical value indicating whether missing values row_var removed calculations. Default FALSE. na.rm.col_var logical value indicating whether missing values col_var removed calculations. Default FALSE. pivot character string determines format table. default, longer returns data long format. return data wide format, specify wider. character string vector strings indicating types summary data return. default NULL, includes counts percentages. return one type, specify count percent. ignore optional named vector list defines values exclude row_var col_var. set NULL (default), values retained. exclude multiple values row_var col_var, supply named list.

what: Summarize continuous variables by group — mean_group_tbl
title: Summarize continuous variables by group — mean_group_tbl
text: mean_group_tbl() calculates descriptive statistics (mean, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, number non-missing observations) interval ratio-level variables share common prefix (variable stem), grouped either another variable dataset matched pattern variable names. variable 'stem' shared naming pattern across related variables, often representing repeated measures concept series items measuring single construct. default, missing data excluded using listwise deletion.

title: Summarize continuous variables by group — mean_group_tbl
code: mean_group_tbl(   data,   var_stem,   group,   escape_stem = FALSE,   ignore_stem_case = FALSE,   group_type = "variable",   group_name = NULL,   escape_group = FALSE,   ignore_group_case = FALSE,   remove_group_non_alnum = TRUE,   na_removal = "listwise",   only = NULL,   var_labels = NULL,   ignore = NULL )

title: Summarize continuous variables by group — mean_group_tbl
text: data data frame. var_stem character string variable stem full name variable data. group character string representing variable name pattern used search variables data. escape_stem logical value indicating whether escape var_stem. Default FALSE. ignore_stem_case logical value indicating whether search columns matching supplied var_stem case-insensitive. Default FALSE. group_type character string defines group argument interpreted. one pattern variable. Defaults variable, searches matching variable name data. group_name optional character string used rename group column final table. group_type set variable, column name defaults matched variable name data. set pattern, default column name group. escape_group logical value indicating whether escape string supplied group. ignore_group_case logical value specifying whether search grouping variable (group_type variable) variables matching pattern (group_type pattern) case-insensitive. Default FALSE. Set TRUE ignore case. remove_group_non_alnum logical value indicating whether remove non- alphanumeric characters (.e., anything letter number) group. Default TRUE. na_removal character string specifies method handling missing values: pairwise listwise. Defaults listwise. character string vector character strings specifying summary statistics return. Defaults NULL, includes mean (mean), standard deviation (sd), minimum (min), maximum (max), count non-missing values (nobs). var_labels optional named character vector list used assign custom labels variable names. element named correspond variable returned table. element unnamed references variable returned table, labels ignored table printed without . ignore optional named vector list defines values exclude variables matching specified variable stem , applicable, grouping variable data. set NULL (default), values retained. exclude values variables identified var_stem, use stem name key. exclude multiple values var_stem variables grouping variable, supply named list.

title: Summarize continuous variables by group — mean_group_tbl
text: tibble presenting summary statistics continuous variables share common stem names. statistics grouped either specified grouping variable within dataset matched pattern variable names.

code: select_group_tbl(data = stem_social_psych,                  var_stem = "belong_belong",                  group = "\\d",                  group_type = "pattern",                  group_name = "wave",                  na_removal = "pairwise",                  pivot = "wider",                  only = "count") #> # A tibble: 2 × 7 #>   variable         wave  count_value_1 count_value_2 count_value_3 count_value_4 #>   <chr>            <chr>         <int>         <int>         <int>         <int> #> 1 belong_belongSt… 1                22            50           144           264 #> 2 belong_belongSt… 2                12            12            48           125 #> # ℹ 1 more variable: count_value_5 <int>  tas_recoded <-   tas |>   dplyr::mutate(sex = dplyr::case_when(     sex == 1 ~ "female",     sex == 2 ~ "male",     TRUE ~ NA)) |>   dplyr::mutate(dplyr::across(     .cols = dplyr::starts_with("involved_"),     .fns = ~ dplyr::case_when(       .x == 1 ~ "selected",       .x == 0 ~ "unselected",       TRUE ~ NA)   ))  select_group_tbl(data = tas_recoded,                  var_stem = "involved_",                  group = "sex",                  group_type = "variable",                  na_removal = "pairwise",                  pivot = "wider") #> # title: Summarize multiple response variables — select_tbl
text: select_tbl() displays frequency counts percentages (.e., count percent) multiple response variables, including binary variables (Unselected/Selected) ordinal variables (responses ranging strongly disagree strongly agree), share common variable stem. variable 'stem' shared naming pattern across related variables, often representing repeated measures concept series items measuring single construct. Missing data excluded using listwise deletion default.

title: Summarize multiple response variables — select_tbl
code: select_tbl(   data,   var_stem,   escape_stem = FALSE,   ignore_stem_case = FALSE,   na_removal = "listwise",   pivot = "longer",   only = NULL,   var_labels = NULL,   ignore = NULL )

title: Summarize multiple response variables — select_tbl
text: data data frame. var_stem character string variable stem full name variable data. escape_stem logical value indicating whether escape var_stem. Default FALSE. ignore_stem_case logical value indicating whether search columns matching supplied var_stem case-insensitive. Default FALSE. na_removal character string specifies method handling missing values: pairwise listwise. Defaults listwise. pivot character string determines format table. default, longer returns data long format. receive data wide format, specify wider. character string vector character strings types summary data return. Default NULL, returns counts percentages. return counts percentages, use count percent, respectively. var_labels optional named character vector list used assign custom labels variable names. element named correspond variable returned table. element unnamed references variable returned table, labels ignored table printed without . ignore optional vector values exclude variables matching specified variable stem. Defaults NULL, retains values.

title: Summarize multiple response variables — select_tbl
text: tibble showing relative frequencies /percentages multiple response variables sharing common variable stem.
